soln_description:
Solution. Let $\omega(x)=x$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega_{1}(x)=\int_{0}^{1} x^{2} t^{2} t d t=\frac{x^{2}}{4} \\
& \omega_{2}(x)=\int_{0}^{1} x^{2} t^{4} \frac{1}{4} d t=\frac{1}{4} x^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{5} \\
& \omega_{3}(x)=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{4 \cdot 5} x^{2} t^{4} d t=\frac{1}{4 \cdot 5^{2}} x^{2} \\
& \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \\
& \omega_{n}(x)=\frac{1}{4 \cdot 5^{n-1}} x^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Next,

$$
\left\|\omega_{n}(x)\right\|=\frac{1}{4 \cdot 5^{n-1}} \sqrt{\int_{0}^{1} x^{4} d x}=\frac{1}{4 \cdot 5^{n-1}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}
$$

Thus, according to (7),

$$
\lambda_{1} \approx \frac{\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{5^{n-2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}}{\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{5^{n-1}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}}}=5
$$

## Problems for Independent Solution

Using the Kellogg method, find the smallest characteristic numbers of the following kernels:

347. $K(x, t)=x t$;

$0 \leqslant x, t \leqslant 1$.

348. $K(x, t)=\sin x \sin t$;

$-\pi \leqslant x, t \leqslant \pi$.

349. $K(x, t)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}t, & x \geqslant t ; \\ x, & x \leqslant t ;\end{array} \quad 0 \leqslant x, t \leqslant 1\right.$.
350. $K(x, t)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{1}{2} x(2-t), \quad x \leqslant t, \\ \frac{1}{2} t(2-x), \quad x \geqslant t,\end{array} \quad 0 \leqslant x, t \leqslant 1\right.$.

Stability of a Compressed Rod (Longitudinal Bending of a Rod)

The equation of the deflected elastic line of the rod is

$$
\frac{d}{d x}\left(E I \frac{d y}{d x}\right)=M
$$

where $\boldsymbol{M}$ is the bending moment, $I$ is the moment of inertia of the cross-section of the rod with abscissa $x$, and $E$ is the Young's modulus.

Consider the case when the rod is compressed by forces applied to its ends. The magnitude of each of these forces is denoted by $P$. Then $M=-\boldsymbol{P} \cdot \boldsymbol{y}$ and equation (9) becomes

$$
\frac{d}{d x}\left(E I \frac{d y}{d x}\right)+P \cdot y=0
$$

The ends of the rod do not move in the direction perpendicular to the rod, so

$$
y(0)=y(l)=0,
$$

where $l$ is the length of the rod. Dividing both sides of equation (10) by $E$ and setting $\frac{\boldsymbol{P}}{\boldsymbol{E}}=\lambda$, we get

$$
\frac{d}{d x}\left(r \frac{d y}{d x}\right)+\lambda y=0
$$

Let $G(x, t)$ be the Green's function of the differential equation (12) with boundary conditions (11). Then the problem (12)-(11) is equivalent to the problem of solving the homogeneous Fredholm integral equation of the second kind

$$
y(x)=\lambda \int_{0}^{l} G(x, t) y(t) d t
$$

The kernel $G(x, t)$ of equation (13) is symmetric as the Green's function of a self-adjoint boundary value problem. Thus, the deflection $y(x)$ of the compressed rod satisfies the integral equation (13). For an arbitrarily chosen force $P$, the number $\lambda=\frac{P}{E}$ will not be a characteristic number, and the solution of equation (13) will be the function $y(x) \equiv 0$. In other words, an arbitrarily chosen compressive force will leave the rod straight. In the case when
$P=\lambda_{n} E$, where $\lambda_{n}$ is a characteristic number of the kernel $G(x, t)$, equation (13) will have a non-zero solution, which corresponds to the bending of the rod, i.e., the loss of its stability.

The smallest force $P$ at which the rod loses stability is called the critical force. It is obviously equal to $P_{\text {cr }}=\lambda_{1} E$, where $\lambda_{1}$ is the smallest characteristic number of equation (13). For practical purposes, a sufficiently good approximate formula is

$$
\lambda_{1} \approx \frac{1}{\sqrt{\int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1} G^{2}(x, t) d x d t}}
$$

which gives $\lambda_{1}$ with a deficiency.
informal_statement: Example 3. Using the Kellogg method, calculate the smallest characteristic number of the kernel $K(x, t)=x^{2} t^{2}, 0 \leqslant x, t \leqslant 1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 3. Using the Kellogg method, calculate the smallest characteristic number of the kernel $K(x, t)=x^{2} t^{2}, 0 \leqslant x, t \leqslant 1$. -/
theorem calculus_148014 (K : ℝ → ℝ → ℝ)
  (hK : K = λ x t => x^2 * t^2) :
  IsLeast {n | ∃ x t, x ∈ Icc 0 1 ∧ t ∈ Icc 0 1 ∧ K x t = n} 5 :=

soln_description:
If $p$ is composite, we choose $a \in \llbracket 1, p-1 \rrbracket$ dividing $p$. $p$ and $(p-1)!$ then have a common factor, so they are not coprime. $p$ is therefore not prime, otherwise it would divide $(p-1)!$ and thus also an integer less than $p-1$.

Conversely, suppose $p$ is prime. There are then two methods to obtain the required congruence.

First method. We will partition $(\mathbb{Z} / p \mathbb{Z})^{*}$ into pairs of elements that are inverses of each other. For this, we need to know the $x \in (\mathbb{Z} / p \mathbb{Z})^{*}$ that are their own inverse; these are roots of the polynomial $X^{2}-\overline{1}$, of degree 2, so there are at most two: these are $\overline{1}$ and $-\overline{1}=\overline{p-1}$. We group the others into pairs of inverses $\left\{x_{i}, x_{i}^{-1}\right\}$, so that $\{\overline{1}\},\{\overline{p-1}\}$ and the $\left\{x_{i}, x_{i}^{-1}\right\}$ form a partition of $(\mathbb{Z} / \mathrm{p} \mathbb{Z})^{*}$.

By reorganizing the order of the factors of the product, we then have

$$
\overline{(p-1)!}=\overline{1} \cdot \overline{p-1} \cdot\left(x_{1} x_{1}^{-1}\right) \cdot \ldots \cdot\left(x_{r} x_{r}^{-1}\right)=\overline{p-1}=-\overline{1}
$$

Second method. For $p=2$, the result is true. Suppose now that $p \geqslant 3$. Consider the polynomial $P(X)=X^{p-1}-1 \in \mathbb{Z} / p \mathbb{Z}[X]$. It is monic and of degree $p-1$, and by Fermat's little theorem, all $p-1$ elements of $(\mathbb{Z} / p \mathbb{Z})^{*}$ are roots of it. By the remark preceding the exercise, we deduce that $P(X)=(X-\overline{1})(X-\overline{2}) \ldots(X-\overline{p-1})$. Since the polynomial $P$ is of even degree, its constant coefficient is the product of its roots, in other words $\overline{(p-1)!}=-\overline{1}$.
informal_statement:
Let $p \geqslant 2$ be a natural number. Show that $p$ is prime if and only if $(p-1)!\equiv-1$ $\bmod p$.

(Wilson's Theorem)
informal_proof:
Let $p$ be a natural number such that $p \geq 2$. We want to show that $p$ is a prime number if and only if $(p-1)! \equiv -1 \pmod p$.

We will prove this biconditional statement by establishing each of the two implications separately.

First, we prove the forward implication: If $p$ is prime, then $(p-1)! \equiv -1 \pmod p$.
We are given that $p$ is a prime number, and $p \geq 2$. A known mathematical result, Wilson's Theorem, states that for any prime number $p$, the congruence $(p-1)! \equiv -1 \pmod p$ holds. Therefore, assuming $p$ is prime directly implies the desired congruence.

Next, we prove the backward implication: If $(p-1)! \equiv -1 \pmod p$, then $p$ is prime.
We are given that $p \geq 2$ and that $(p-1)! \equiv -1 \pmod p$. Again, Wilson's Theorem states that this congruence holds if and only if $p$ is prime. Thus, the given congruence implies that $p$ must be a prime number.

Since we have shown both directions of the biconditional, we have proven that $p$ is prime if and only if $(p-1)! \equiv -1 \pmod p$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Nat

/- Let $p \geqslant 2$ be a natural number. Show that $p$ is prime if and only if $(p-1)!\equiv-1$ $\bmod p$.

(Wilson's Theorem) -/
theorem number_theory_151603 {p : ℕ} (hp : 2 ≤ p) :
    Nat.Prime p ↔ ((p - 1) ! : ZMod p) = -1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Nat

theorem number_theory_151603 {p : ℕ} (hp : 2 ≤ p) :
    Nat.Prime p ↔ ((p - 1) ! : ZMod p) = -1 := by
  apply Iff.intro
  · -- Forward: if p is prime, then (p - 1)! ≡ -1 (mod p)
    intro h
    apply (Nat.prime_iff_fac_equiv_neg_one (by linarith)).mp
    exact h
  · -- Backward: if (p - 1)! ≡ -1 (mod p), then p is prime
    intro h
    apply (Nat.prime_iff_fac_equiv_neg_one (by linarith)).mpr
    exact h

informal_statement: Let $\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{z}$ be vectors in $\mathbb{R}^3$. Prove that the volume of the parallelepiped defined by the set $\{r\mathbf{x} + s\mathbf{y} + t\mathbf{z} \mid 0 \leq r, s, t \leq 1\}$ is equal to $|\det(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{z})|$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{z}$ be vectors in $\mathbb{R}^3$. Prove that the volume of the parallelepiped defined by the set $\{r\mathbf{x} + s\mathbf{y} + t\mathbf{z} \mid 0 \leq r, s, t \leq 1\}$ is equal to $|\det(\mathbf{x}, \mathbf{y}, \mathbf{z})|$. -/
theorem algebra_1518 (x y z : Fin 3 → ℝ) :
  (MeasureTheory.volume {p : Fin 3 → ℝ | ∃ r s t : ℝ, p = r • x + s • y + t • z ∧ 0 ≤ r ∧ r ≤ 1 ∧ 0 ≤ s ∧ s ≤ 1 ∧ 0 ≤ t ∧ t ≤ 1}).toReal =
  |(x 0) * (y 1) * (z 2) + (x 1) * (y 2) * (z 0) + (x 2) * (y 0) * (z 1) - (x 0) * (y 2) * (z 1) - (x 1) * (y 0) * (z 2) - (x 2) * (y 1) * (z 0)| := by

informal_statement: Find the number of positive integers $n,$ $1 \le n \le 100,$ for which $x^{2n} + 1 + (x + 1)^{2n}$ is divisible by $x^2 + x + 1.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the number of positive integers $n,$ $1 \le n \le 100,$ for which $x^{2n} + 1 + (x + 1)^{2n}$ is divisible by $x^2 + x + 1.$ -/
theorem algebra_21446 :
    Set.ncard {n : ℕ | 1 ≤ n ∧ n ≤ 100 ∧ (X ^ 2 + X + 1 : Polynomial ℤ) ∣ X ^ (2 * n) + 1 + (X + 1) ^ (2 * n)} = 67 := by

soln_description:
$\cos 2 \alpha=\cos (\alpha+\alpha)=\cos ^{2} \alpha-\sin ^{2} \alpha=2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-1$, and $\cos 3 \alpha=\cos (2 \alpha+\alpha)=\left(2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-\right.$ 1) $\cos \alpha-(2 \sin \alpha \cos \alpha) \sin \alpha=4 \cos ^{3} \alpha-3 \cos \alpha$, so $Q(x)=4 x^{3}-3 x$.

This polynomial is useful for question b). Indeed, it equals 1 when $3 \alpha$ is a multiple of $2 \pi$, i.e., when $x=\cos \alpha=1$ or $\frac{-1}{2}$, and equals -1 when $3 \alpha$ is an odd multiple of $\pi$, i.e., when $x=\cos \alpha=\frac{1}{2}$ or -1. For any other value of $x=\cos \alpha \in[-1,1]$, $Q(x)$ is between -1 and 1. Therefore, for $a=0, b=-3, c=0, M=1$.

If a polynomial $P(x)$ satisfied for all $x \in[-1,1]|P(x)|0,(P-Q)\left(\frac{-1}{2}0\right.$ and $(P-Q)(1)\frac{1}{2}$ in which case $\mathrm{P}(-1)0$ : contradiction in both cases. The polynomial $Q$ is thus the unique case of equality.
informal_statement:
a) Determine the polynomial $\mathrm{Q}$ such that for any real $\alpha, \mathrm{Q}(\cos \alpha)=\cos 3 \alpha$.

b) Let $a, b, c$ be any real numbers, $P(x)=4 x^{3}+a x^{2}+b x+c$ and $M$ the maximum value of $|P(x)|$ on $[-1,1]$. Show that $M \geqslant 1$. In what case do we have equality?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- a) Determine the polynomial $\mathrm{Q}$ such that for any real $\alpha, \mathrm{Q}(\cos \alpha)=\cos 3 \alpha$.

b) Let $a, b, c$ be any real numbers, $P(x)=4 x^{3}+a x^{2}+b x+c$ and $M$ the maximum value of $|P(x)|$ on $[-1,1]$. Show that $M \geqslant 1$. In what case do we have equality? -/
theorem algebra_151296 {Q : ℝ → ℝ} (hQ : ∀ α, Q (cos α) = cos (3 * α)) :
    Q = λ x => 4 * x ^ 3 - 3 * x := by

informal_statement:
# Problem 8. (4 points)

Solve the equation $p^{2}-58 p=2 q^{2}-26 q-697$ in prime numbers. In your answer, list all possible values of $p$ in ascending order, separated by commas or semicolons.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- # Problem 8. (4 points)

Solve the equation $p^{2}-58 p=2 q^{2}-26 q-697$ in prime numbers. In your answer, list all possible values of $p$ in ascending order, separated by commas or semicolons. -/
theorem number_theory_211362 (p q : ℕ) (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime)
    (h : p^2 - 58 * p = 2 * q^2 - 26 * q - 697) :
    p = 17 ∨ p = 19 ∨ p = 37 ∨ p = 41 := by

soln_description:
6. 4 .

It is easy to see that $n \geqslant 4$ (2, 4, 7, 9 must be in four different sets).
Also, when $n=4$, the sets
$$
A_{i}=\left\{m \in \mathbf{Z}_{+} \mid m \equiv i(\bmod 4)\right\}(i=0,1,2,3)
$$

satisfy the condition.
Therefore, the minimum value of $n$ is 4.
informal_statement: 6. Given that all positive integers are in $n$ sets, satisfying that when $|i-j|$ is a prime number, $i$ and $j$ belong to two different sets. Then the minimum value of $n$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Given that all positive integers are in $n$ sets, satisfying that when $|i-j|$ is a prime number, $i$ and $j$ belong to two different sets. Then the minimum value of $n$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem number_theory_322371 (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 0) (a : ℕ → Fin n)
    (ha : ∀ i j, Prime (Nat.dist i j) → a i ≠ a j) :
    n ≥ 4 := by

soln_description:
Let $x$ be the abscissa of an intersection point of the two curves. Then it holds that $2 x^{2}=\frac{1}{3} x+z$ or $x^{2}-\frac{1}{6} x-\frac{1}{2} z=0$, thus

$$
x=\frac{1}{12} \pm \sqrt{\frac{1}{144}+\frac{z}{2}}=\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1+72 z}}{12}
$$

Case 1: It is $x=\frac{1+\sqrt{1+72 z}}{12} \in \mathbb{Z}$. Then, because

$$
0\frac{1-\sqrt{1+72 \cdot 1}}{12} \geq x=\frac{1-\sqrt{1+72 z}}{12} \geq \frac{1-\sqrt{1+72 \cdot 5}}{12}=\frac{1-19}{12}>\frac{-24}{12}=-2
$$

thus $x=-1$. Then $y=2 x^{2}=2$ and therefore $z=y-\frac{1}{3} x=\frac{7}{3}$.

Thus, there are exactly in the two cases $z=\frac{5}{3}$ and $z=\frac{7}{3}$ in the considered interval for $z$ intersection points with integer abscissas, namely in the first case the point (1|2) and in the second the point $(-1 \mid 2)$. (The other intersection points, if they exist, do not have integer abscissas, as they would have had to appear as solutions in the respective cases.)
informal_statement:
## Task 4 - 241234

Determine all real numbers $z$ with $1 \leq z \leq 5$ that satisfy the condition that the line with the equation $y=\frac{1}{3} x+z$ and the parabola with the equation $y=2 x^{2}$ have at least one intersection point with an integer abscissa.

For each number $z$ that satisfies this condition, provide - for the relevant line and parabola - the coordinates of all intersection points with an integer abscissa.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task 4 - 241234

Determine all real numbers $z$ with $1 \leq z \leq 5$ that satisfy the condition that the line with the equation $y=\frac{1}{3} x+z$ and the parabola with the equation $y=2 x^{2}$ have at least one intersection point with an integer abscissa.

For each number $z$ that satisfies this condition, provide - for the relevant line and parabola - the coordinates of all intersection points with an integer abscissa. -/
theorem algebra_198910 (z : ℝ) (hz : 1 ≤ z ∧ z ≤ 5) :
    ∃ x : ℤ, (1 / 3) * x + z = 2 * x ^ 2 ↔ z = 5 / 3 ∨ z = 7 / 3 := by

soln_description:
Solution. We have

$$
|z-2 i|=\left|\frac{2}{5}(z-5 i)+\frac{3}{5} z\right| \leq \frac{2}{5}|z-5 i|+\frac{3}{5}|z|
$$

Similarly,

$$
|z-3 i|=\left|\frac{3}{5}(z-5 i)+\frac{2}{5} z\right| \leq \frac{3}{5}|z-5 i|+\frac{2}{5}|z|
$$

from which we get

$$
|z|+|z-5 i| \geq|z-2 i|+|z-3 i|
$$

Equality holds when there exists $\lambda \geq 0$ such that $z-5 i=\lambda z$, from which we deduce that $z=a i$, with $a \in(-\infty, 0] \cup[5,+\infty)$. $(3 \text{p})$
informal_statement:
Problem 3. Determine the complex numbers $z$ for which the relation holds

$$
|z|+|z-5 i|=|z-2 i|+|z-3 i|
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Problem 3. Determine the complex numbers $z$ for which the relation holds

$$
|z|+|z-5 i|=|z-2 i|+|z-3 i|
$$ -/
theorem algebra_111656 (z : ℂ) :
  abs z + abs (z - 5 * .I) = abs (z - 2 * .I) + abs (z - 3 * .I) ↔
  z.re ≤ 0 ∨ z.im ≥ 5 := by

informal_statement: Given the function $f(x)=2({{\sin }^{4}}x+{{\cos }^{4}}x)+m{{(\sin x+\cos x)}^{4}}$ has a maximum value of $5$ for $x\in [0,\frac{ \pi }{2}]$, find the value of the real number $m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- Given the function $f(x)=2({{\sin }^{4}}x+{{\cos }^{4}}x)+m{{(\sin x+\cos x)}^{4}}$ has a maximum value of $5$ for $x\in [0,\frac{ \pi }{2}]$, find the value of the real number $m$. -/
theorem algebra_12420 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (m : ℝ)
  (h₀ : ∀ x, f x = 2 * (sin x ^ 4 + cos x ^ 4) + m * (sin x + cos x) ^ 4)
  (h₁ : IsGreatest (image f (Icc 0 (π/2))) 5) :
  m = 1 := by

informal_statement: Show that every non-zero natural number is a product of prime numbers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that every non-zero natural number is a product of prime numbers. -/
theorem number_theory_164602 {n : ℕ} (hn : n ≠ 0) :
    ∃ p : Finset ℕ, n = ∏ i ∈ p, i ∧ ∀ i ∈ p, Nat.Prime i := by

soln_description:
1. **Define the function \( g(x) \):**
   Let \( g(x) = f'(x) - 3f(x) \) for all \( x \geq 0 \).

2. **Transform the given differential inequality:**
   Given \( f''(x) - 5f'(x) + 6f(x) \geq 0 \), we can rewrite it in terms of \( g(x) \):
   \[
   f''(x) - 5f'(x) + 6f(x) = (f''(x) - 3f'(x)) - 2(f'(x) - 3f(x)) = g'(x) - 2g(x) \geq 0
   \]
   This implies:
   \[
   g'(x) - 2g(x) \geq 0
   \]

3. **Introduce a new function \( p(x) \):**
   Let \( p(x) = e^{-2x}g(x) \) for all \( x \geq 0 \). Then, we compute the derivative of \( p(x) \):
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} p(x) = \frac{d}{dx} \left( e^{-2x}g(x) \right) = e^{-2x}g'(x) - 2e^{-2x}g(x) = e^{-2x}(g'(x) - 2g(x))
   \]
   Since \( g'(x) - 2g(x) \geq 0 \), it follows that:
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} p(x) \geq 0
   \]
   Therefore, \( p(x) \) is an increasing function.

4. **Evaluate \( p(x) \) at \( x = 0 \):**
   \[
   p(0) = e^{-2 \cdot 0} g(0) = g(0) = f'(0) - 3f(0) = 0 - 3 \cdot 1 = -3
   \]
   Since \( p(x) \) is increasing, for all \( x \geq 0 \):
   \[
   p(x) \geq p(0) = -3
   \]
   Thus:
   \[
   e^{-2x}g(x) \geq -3 \quad \text{or} \quad g(x) \geq -3e^{2x}
   \]

5. **Define another function \( q(x) \):**
   Let \( q(x) = e^{-3x}f(x) - 3e^{-x} \) for all \( x \geq 0 \). Then, we compute the derivative of \( q(x) \):
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} q(x) = \frac{d}{dx} \left( e^{-3x}f(x) - 3e^{-x} \right) = e^{-3x}f'(x) - 3e^{-3x}f(x) + 3e^{-x} = e^{-3x}(f'(x) - 3f(x)) + 3e^{-x}
   \]
   Since \( f'(x) - 3f(x) = g(x) \), we have:
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} q(x) = e^{-3x}g(x) + 3e^{-x}
   \]
   Using the inequality \( g(x) \geq -3e^{2x} \), we get:
   \[
   e^{-3x}g(x) \geq e^{-3x}(-3e^{2x}) = -3e^{-x}
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   \frac{d}{dx} q(x) = e^{-3x}g(x) + 3e^{-x} \geq -3e^{-x} + 3e^{-x} = 0
   \]
   Thus, \( q(x) \) is an increasing function.

6. **Evaluate \( q(x) \) at \( x = 0 \):**
   \[
   q(0) = e^{-3 \cdot 0} f(0) - 3e^{-0} = f(0) - 3 = 1 - 3 = -2
   \]
   Since \( q(x) \) is increasing, for all \( x \geq 0 \):
   \[
   q(x) \geq q(0) = -2
   \]
   Thus:
   \[
   e^{-3x}f(x) - 3e^{-x} \geq -2 \quad \text{or} \quad e^{-3x}f(x) \geq 3e^{-x} - 2
   \]
   Multiplying both sides by \( e^{3x} \), we get:
   \[
   f(x) \geq 3e^{2x} - 2e^{3x}
   \]

The final answer is \( \boxed{ f(x) \geq 3e^{2x} - 2e^{3x} } \)
informal_statement:
Suppose $f:\mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{R}$ is a two times differentiable function satisfying $f(0)=1,f^{\prime}(0)=0$ and for all $x\in [0,\infty)$, it satisfies 
\[ f^{\prime \prime}(x)-5f^{\prime}(x)+6f(x)\ge 0 \]
Prove that, for all $x\in [0,\infty)$,
\[ f(x)\ge 3e^{2x}-2e^{3x} \]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Suppose $f:\mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{R}$ is a two times differentiable function satisfying $f(0)=1,f^{\prime}(0)=0$ and for all $x\in [0,\infty)$, it satisfies 
\[ f^{\prime \prime}(x)-5f^{\prime}(x)+6f(x)\ge 0 \]
Prove that, for all $x\in [0,\infty)$,
\[ f(x)\ge 3e^{2x}-2e^{3x} \] -/
theorem calculus_52029 {f : ℝ → ℝ}
  (hf0 : f 0 = 1) (hf1 : deriv f 0 = 0)
  (hfn : ∀ x ≥ 0, iteratedDeriv 2 f x - 5 * deriv f x + 6 * f x ≥ 0) :
  ∀ x ≥ 0, f x ≥ 3 * exp (2 * x) - 2 * exp (3 * x) :=

soln_description:
The obtained number must be divisible by $7 \cdot 8 \cdot 9=504.523000=1037 \cdot 504+352$. Since $504-352=152$, numbers divisible by 504 are 523152 and

$523152+504=523656$.

## Answer

523152 or 523656.
informal_statement:
[ Decimal number system ] [ GCD and LCM. Mutual simplicity ]

Complete the number 523... with three digits so that the resulting six-digit number is divisible by 7, 8, and 9.

#
informal_proof:
We want to prove that for a natural number \(n\) such that \(n < 1000\), the condition that \(n + 523000\) is divisible by 7, 8, and 9 holds if and only if \(n\) is either 152 or 656. We will prove both directions of this biconditional statement.

**Forward Direction: If \(n+523000\) is divisible by 7, 8, and 9, then \(n = 152\) or \(n = 656\).**

Assume that \(n\) is a natural number with \(n < 1000\), and that \(n + 523000\) is divisible by 7, 8, and 9.
Since 7, 8, and 9 are pairwise coprime, their least common multiple is $7 \times 8 \times 9 = 504$.
Therefore, if \(n + 523000\) is divisible by 7, 8, and 9, it must also be divisible by 504.
This can be expressed using modular arithmetic as:
$n + 523000 \equiv 0 \pmod{504}$
which implies:
$n \equiv -523000 \pmod{504}$

Now, we find the remainder of 523000 when divided by 504:
$523000 = 1037 \times 504 + 352$
So, $523000 \equiv 352 \pmod{504}$.

Substituting this back into our congruence for \(n\):
$n \equiv -352 \pmod{504}$
To express this with a positive remainder, we add 504:
$n \equiv -352 + 504 \pmod{504}$
$n \equiv 152 \pmod{504}$

We are given that \(n < 1000\). We need to find all natural numbers \(n\) such that \(n \equiv 152 \pmod{504}\) and \(n < 1000\).
The possible values for \(n\) are of the form $152 + 504k$ for some integer $k$.
\begin{itemize}
    \item If $k=0$, $n = 152$. This satisfies $n < 1000$.
    \item If $k=1$, $n = 152 + 504 = 656$. This satisfies $n < 1000$.
    \item If $k=2$, $n = 152 + 504 \times 2 = 152 + 1008 = 1160$. This does not satisfy $n < 1000$.
\end{itemize}
Therefore, if the divisibility conditions hold, \(n\) must be either 152 or 656.

**Backward Direction: If \(n = 152\) or \(n = 656\), then \(n+523000\) is divisible by 7, 8, and 9.**

We consider the two cases for \(n\):

**Case 1: \(n = 152\)**
We need to verify that $152 + 523000$ is divisible by 7, 8, and 9.
$152 + 523000 = 523152$.
\begin{itemize}
    \item Divisibility by 7: $523152 \div 7 = 74736$. Since the result is an integer, 523152 is divisible by 7.
    \item Divisibility by 8: $523152 \div 8 = 65394$. Since the result is an integer, 523152 is divisible by 8.
    \item Divisibility by 9: The sum of the digits of 523152 is $5+2+3+1+5+2 = 18$. Since 18 is divisible by 9, 523152 is divisible by 9.
\end{itemize}
Thus, if $n = 152$, the conditions are satisfied.

**Case 2: \(n = 656\)**
We need to verify that $656 + 523000$ is divisible by 7, 8, and 9.
$656 + 523000 = 523656$.
\begin{itemize}
    \item Divisibility by 7: $523656 \div 7 = 74808$. Since the result is an integer, 523656 is divisible by 7.
    \item Divisibility by 8: $523656 \div 8 = 65457$. Since the result is an integer, 523656 is divisible by 8.
    \item Divisibility by 9: The sum of the digits of 523656 is $5+2+3+6+5+6 = 27$. Since 27 is divisible by 9, 523656 is divisible by 9.
\end{itemize}
Thus, if $n = 656$, the conditions are satisfied.

Since both directions of the biconditional statement have been proven, the original statement is true.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- [ Decimal number system ] [ GCD and LCM. Mutual simplicity ]

Complete the number 523... with three digits so that the resulting six-digit number is divisible by 7, 8, and 9.

# -/
theorem number_theory_215981 (n : ℕ) (h₀ : n < 1000) :
    7 ∣ (n + 523000) ∧ 8 ∣ (n + 523000) ∧ 9 ∣ (n + 523000) ↔
    n = 152 ∨ n = 656 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_215981 (n : ℕ) (h₀ : n < 1000) :
    7 ∣ (n + 523000) ∧ 8 ∣ (n + 523000) ∧ 9 ∣ (n + 523000) ↔
    n = 152 ∨ n = 656 := by 
  constructor
  · -- Forward direction: if 7, 8, and 9 all divide n + 523000, then n is either 152 or 656
    rintro ⟨h₁, h₂, h₃⟩
    have h4 : n < 1000 := h₀
    interval_cases n <;> omega 
  · -- Backward direction: if n is either 152 or 656, then 7, 8, and 9 all divide n + 523000
    rintro (h | h)
    · -- Case n = 152
      rw [show n = 152 by linarith]
      constructor
      · norm_num 
      constructor
      · norm_num 
      · norm_num 
    · -- Case n = 656
      rw [show n = 656 by linarith]
      constructor
      · norm_num 
      constructor
      · norm_num 
      · norm_num

soln_description:
Solution. Suppose such an infinite sequence exists. By possibly omitting the first two elements, we can ensure that the first prime number in the sequence is at least 5. We thus assume without loss of generality that $p_{0} \geq 5$. Then we know that $p_{0} \not \equiv 0 \bmod 3$.

Suppose that $p_{0} \equiv 1 \bmod 3$. We then prove by induction on $k$ that for all positive integers $k$ it holds that: $p_{k} \equiv 1 \bmod 3$ and $p_{k}=2 p_{k-1}-1$. Namely, suppose that $k \geq 1$ and $p_{k-1} \equiv 1 \bmod 3$. Then $2 p_{k-1} \equiv 2 \bmod 3$, so $2 p_{k-1}+1$ is divisible by 3. Since $p_{k}$ must be a prime number greater than 3, it follows that $p_{k}=2 p_{k-1}-1$ and $p_{k} \equiv 2-1 \equiv 1 \bmod 3$. This completes the induction.

If precisely $p_{0} \equiv 2 \bmod 3$, then we can prove analogously that $p_{k} \equiv 2 \bmod 3$ and $p_{k}=2 p_{k-1}+1$ for all positive integers $k$.

We can now derive a direct formula for the sequence. If $p_{0} \equiv 1 \bmod 3$, then we get $p_{k}=\left(p_{0}-1\right) 2^{k}+1$ for all $k \geq 0$. If $p_{0} \equiv 2 \bmod 3$, then we get $p_{k}=\left(p_{0}+1\right) 2^{k}-1$. We can prove these formulas simply by induction.

According to Fermat's Little Theorem, $2^{p_{0}-1} \equiv 1 \bmod p_{0}$, so also $\left(-p_{0}+1\right) 2^{p_{0}-1} \equiv 1 \bmod p_{0}$ and $\left(p_{0}+1\right) 2^{p_{0}-1} \equiv 1 \bmod p_{0}$. From this it follows that $p_{0} \mid\left(p_{0}-1\right) 2^{p_{0}-1}+1$ and $p_{0} \mid \left(p_{0}+1\right) 2^{p_{0}-1}-1$. We see that $p_{0}$ is always a divisor of $p_{p_{0}-1}$. Since it is also clear that $p_{p_{0}-1}$ is greater than $p_{0}$, it follows that $p_{p_{0}-1}$ is not a prime number. Contradiction.
informal_statement:
Task 4. Prove that there does not exist an infinite sequence of prime numbers $p_{0}, p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots$ with the property that for all positive integers $k$:

$$
p_{k}=2 p_{k-1}+1 \quad \text { or } \quad p_{k}=2 p_{k-1}-1
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Task 4. Prove that there does not exist an infinite sequence of prime numbers $p_{0}, p_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots$ with the property that for all positive integers $k$:

$$
p_{k}=2 p_{k-1}+1 \quad \text { or } \quad p_{k}=2 p_{k-1}-1
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_170550 :
    ¬∃ p : ℕ → ℕ,
      (∀ n, Nat.Prime (p n)) ∧
      (∀ k, p (k + 1) = 2 * p k + 1 ∨ p (k + 1) = 2 * p k - 1) := by

soln_description:
(i) If $n$ is odd, let $n=2k+1$, where $k$ is an integer greater than 2. Then write $n=k+(k+1)$, and it is clear that $(k, k+1)=1$, so this representation meets the requirement.
(ii) If $n$ is even, then we can set $n=4k$ or $4k+2$, where $k$ is a natural number greater than 1.

When $n=4k$, we can write $n=(2k-1)+(2k+1)$, and it is easy to see that $2k-1$ and $2k+1$ are coprime. If they have a common factor $d \geqslant 2$, then $d \mid 2$, but $2k-1$ and $2k+1$ are both odd, which is impossible.

When $n=4k+2$, we can write $n=(2k-1)+(2k+3)$, and it is easy to see that $2k-1$ and $2k+3$ are coprime. If they have a common factor $d \geqslant 2$, let $2k-1=nd$ and $2k+3=md$, where $m$ and $n$ are natural numbers. Then we get $(m-n)d=4$, which implies $d \mid 4$. This is a contradiction.
Since (i) and (ii) cover all cases, the conclusion is proved.
informal_statement: Three, (25 points) Prove that every natural number $n$ greater than 6 can be expressed as the sum of two natural numbers greater than 1 and coprime to each other.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Three, (25 points) Prove that every natural number $n$ greater than 6 can be expressed as the sum of two natural numbers greater than 1 and coprime to each other.

 -/
theorem number_theory_309660 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 6) :
    ∃ m k, m > 1 ∧ k > 1 ∧ m + k = n ∧ Nat.Coprime m k := by

informal_statement: A man is in a boat 2 miles from the nearest point, $B$, on a straight coastline. He needs to reach point $Q$, which is 3 miles down the coast from $B$ and 1 mile inland from the coast. If he can row at a speed of 2 miles per hour and walk at a speed of 4 miles per hour, toward what point on the coast should he row in order to minimize the total time taken to reach point $Q$?
informal_proof:
We are given a real number `x` satisfying two conditions: `x > 0`, and the equation `3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x = 3 / 2 + 1 / 4`. Our goal is to prove that `x = 1`.

First, we must ensure that the denominators in the given equation are not zero.
The condition `x > 0` directly implies that `x` is not zero.
Next, we consider the denominator `2 - x`. If `2 - x = 0`, then `x` must be equal to `2`. Let us assume, for the sake of contradiction, that `x = 2`. Substituting `x = 2` into the original equation `3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x = 3 / 2 + 1 / 4` would lead to `3 / (2 - 2) + 1 / 2 = 3 / 2 + 1 / 4`, which involves division by zero (`3 / 0`), an undefined operation. This contradiction confirms that our assumption `x = 2` must be false, and therefore, `2 - x ≠ 0`.

Now that we have established that `x ≠ 0` and `2 - x ≠ 0`, we can simplify the given equation algebraically.
The equation is `3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x = 3 / 2 + 1 / 4`.
The right-hand side simplifies to `6/4 + 1/4 = 7/4`.
So, `3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x = 7 / 4`.
To eliminate the denominators, we find a common denominator, which is `x(2 - x)`, and multiply both sides of the equation by it:
`x(2 - x) * [3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x] = x(2 - x) * [7 / 4]`
This yields:
`3x + (2 - x) = (7/4) * (2x - x^2)`
`2x + 2 = (7/4) * (2x - x^2)`
Multiplying both sides by 4 to clear the fraction gives:
`4(2x + 2) = 7(2x - x^2)`
`8x + 8 = 14x - 7x^2`
Rearranging all terms to one side, we obtain a quadratic equation:
`7x^2 + 8x - 14x + 8 = 0`
`7x^2 - 6x + 8 = 0`

We now need to show that `x = 1` follows from this equation and the condition `x > 0`.
Let's analyze the quadratic equation `7x^2 - 6x + 8 = 0`. The discriminant of a quadratic equation `ax^2 + bx + c = 0` is given by `Δ = b^2 - 4ac`. In this case, `a = 7`, `b = -6`, and `c = 8`.
The discriminant is `Δ = (-6)^2 - 4 * 7 * 8 = 36 - 224 = -188`.
Since the discriminant is negative (`-188 < 0`) and the leading coefficient (`a = 7`) is positive, the quadratic `7x^2 - 6x + 8` is always positive for all real values of `x`. This means the equation `7x^2 - 6x + 8 = 0` has no real solutions.

The fact that our derived equation has no real solutions implies that the initial premise (the original equation `3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x = 3 / 2 + 1 / 4`) must be false for any real number `x`.
In classical logic, if a premise is false, then any conclusion can be validly deduced from it. Therefore, from the falsity of the initial equation, we can conclude that `x = 1`.
The properties of non-negative squares, such as `(x - 1)^2 ≥ 0`, `(x - 2)^2 ≥ 0`, and `(x - 4/7)^2 ≥ 0`, are fundamental truths about real numbers. By utilizing these and the derived contradictory equation, we demonstrate that the conditions given cannot simultaneously hold for any real `x`, which then allows us to validly assert `x = 1`.

Thus, we have proven that if `x > 0` and `3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x = 3 / 2 + 1 / 4`, then `x = 1`.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- A man is in a boat 2 miles from the nearest point, $B$, on a straight coastline. He needs to reach point $Q$, which is 3 miles down the coast from $B$ and 1 mile inland from the coast. If he can row at a speed of 2 miles per hour and walk at a speed of 4 miles per hour, toward what point on the coast should he row in order to minimize the total time taken to reach point $Q$? -/
theorem calculus_2934 (x : ℝ) (hx : x > 0) (h : 3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x = 3 / 2 + 1 / 4) :
    x = 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem calculus_2934 (x : ℝ) (hx : x > 0) (h : 3 / (2 - x) + 1 / x = 3 / 2 + 1 / 4) :
    x = 1 := by
  have h1 : x ≠ 0 := by linarith
  have h2 : 2 - x ≠ 0 := by
    by_contra h3
    have h4 : x = 2 := by linarith
    rw [h4] at h
    norm_num at h
  field_simp [h2, h1] at h
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (x - 2), sq_nonneg (x - 4 / 7)]

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\int_{2}^{3} \sqrt{\frac{3-2 x}{2 x-7}} d x=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\sqrt{\frac{3-2 x}{2 x-7}} \Rightarrow t^{2}=\frac{3-2 x}{2 x-7}=-\frac{2 x-7+4}{2 x-7}=-1-\frac{4}{2 x-7} \Rightarrow \\
& \Rightarrow 7-2 x=\frac{4}{t^{2}+1} \Rightarrow x=-\frac{2}{t^{2}+1}+\frac{7}{2} \\
& d x=\frac{2}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot 2 t \cdot d t=\frac{4 t}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot d t \\
& x=2 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{3-2 \cdot 2}{2 \cdot 2-7}}=\sqrt{\frac{-1}{-3}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\
& x=3 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{3-2 \cdot 3}{2 \cdot 3-7}}=\sqrt{\frac{-3}{-1}}=\sqrt{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{\sqrt{3}} t \cdot \frac{4 t}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot d t=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\tan z, d t=\frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z} \\
& t=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow z=\arctan \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{\pi}{6} \\
& t=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow z=\arctan \sqrt{3}=\frac{\pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan^{2} z}{\left(\tan^{2} z+1\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z}=4 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan^{2} z}{\left(\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} z}\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z}=4 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \tan^{2} z \cdot \cos ^{2} z \cdot d z= \\
& =4 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \sin ^{2} z \cdot d z=2 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3}(1-\cos 2 z) d z=\left.2 \cdot\left(z-\frac{\sin 2 z}{2}\right)\right|_{\pi / 6} ^{\pi / 3}= \\
& =2 \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{3}-\frac{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{3}}{2}\right)-2 \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{6}-\frac{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{6}}{2}\right)=\frac{2 \pi}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{\pi}{3}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=\frac{\pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$
